body:
Provide a Python syntax version of
```cython
cdef packed struct MyStruct: ...
```
Since `cython.struct()` already takes arbitrary keyword arguments, a new keyword argument `packed=True` will not work.
We could just add a new function `cython.packed_struct()`. (It would just be an alias for `struct()` in `Shadow.py`.)

comment_data.body:
Can we afford to make the structures a little more pythonic? Dataclass-style, only not allowing any other members besides fields and restrict use of `cython.declare` (disallow using `visibility` argument).
This would look prettier:
```python
@cython.struct
class MyStruct:
    x: cython.int
    y: cython.int
    data: cython.double
```

Than this:
```python
MyStruct = cython.struct(x=cython.int, y=cython.int, data=cython.double)

```

And then it will be possible to write the packed structures in this way:
```python
@cython.packed
@cython.struct
class MyStruct:
    x: cython.int
    y: cython.int
    data: cython.double
```

or

```python
@cython.packed_struct
class MyStruct:
    x: cython.int
    y: cython.int
    data: cython.double
```

Or even `class MyStruct(metaclass=cython.struct)` (*half-wink*)

A decorator `@cython.packed` doesn't seem a good idea to me. There is nothing you could combine it with than `@cython.struct`. And `@cython.packed_struct` reads a lot more like the C code that it aims to represent.

Defining C structs in a Python class body seems a very obvious thing to do. It would be nice to support that.

> It would be nice to support that.

Should I create a separate issue dedicated to this?

> restrict use of `cython.declare` (disallow using `visibility` argument).

Of course, it's easier to just not allow visibility to be defined, but in cpp it is possible to define visibility for structure members, we could add this feature, although it seems like a relatively unclaimed feature, and it will take a lot of work to put everything together.

No, not if the intention is to change the class creation. The decorated class is already created when the decorator runs on it.

If you look at the way `cython.struct()` is implemented, that's totally a use case for a metaclass that does its own class creation.

Still, packed structs are a very rare and special thing. I think it's fine to give them their own, separate decorator. Or two, if you want C++ structs.

I just think that
```cython
@cython.packed_struct
class MyStruct: ...
```
reads better than the more verbose
```cython
@cython.packed
@cython.struct
class MyStruct: ...
```
or
```cython
@cython.struct
@cython.packed
class MyStruct: ...
```
In which order would you write the two decorators? Is it "`@packed @struct`" or "`@struct @packed`"? Should that matter? Should people have to decide this each time they write a packed struct? If it's "`@packed @struct`", as you would find it in C, then does that make the "`@struct`" harder to spot? What if multiple developers in the same project feel differently about it?

To me, all of this seems to violate the "don't make me think" principle, big time. With "`@cython.packed_struct`", there is no need to discuss or consider anything.
Well, I agree. Okay, so be it.
